Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - LTREB: Evolutionary Demography - the Contribution of Adaptation and Environment to Population Dynamics, Range Size, and Niche Width
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a 7-year study of environmental and demographic variation across the geographic range of a native California plant in order to understand the ecological and evolutionary limits on an organism's distribution. Prior work showed that environmental variables related to climate, soils, and interactions with insect pollinators and seed-eaters all change across the plant's range. Population growth rates, a measure of population viability, also decline toward the range edge. Over the next five years, research will examine the role that dormant seeds, which remain buried in the soil for 2-5 years, play in allowing populations to weather adverse environments and persist long-term. The project will also determine range-wide differences in the longevity of dormant seeds.

With impending climate change, parts of the current geographic range of many organisms are likely to become unsuitable for continued persistence. Understanding what limits species from colonizing unfavorable environments now can help forecast species responses to deteriorating conditions within their current range. In addition to its scientific impacts, the project will serve an important educational mission by engaging high school students, undergraduate students from research and primarily undergraduate institutions, and graduate students in research. Project leaders will work with high school students from a rural California high school and from a charter school in St Paul Minnesota through in-class activities and field projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the challenges to understanding Earth's breathtaking biodiversity is to explain why species occur where they do and not somewhere else. This project addressed that fundamental question, with long-term studies of a California "wildflower," Clarkia xantiana.  

The plant is beautiful and charismatic, but how can a wildflower stand in for diverse other species, species whose distributions are more critical to understand, perhaps because they are threatened with extinction or have distinct cultural or economic value? The reason is that, across the Tree of Life, species' geographic ranges are determined by the same fundamental biological processes. One of the key processes is population growth. A species can persist in a geographic region only if its long-term population growth rate there allows populations to be stable or to grow. In turn, population growth rates depend on a species' breadth of adaptation to environmental variation: its niche. By focusing on a locally species with a modest geographic range and two decades of intensive field studies by our research team, we have been able to develop Clarkia xantiana into a model for understanding the links between a species' population growth, niche, and geographic range.

The main features of the research were three. The first was long-term monitoring of populations and weather. In every year of the project (and for eight years before it began), we returned to tens of mapped Clarkia xantiana populations season after season, taking detailed censuses of plants at different life stages, and assessing any losses of plants and seeds to insects and mammals that eat them. At the same time, we maintained a network of automated weather stations, which allowed us to characterize daily and seasonal precipitation and temperature within the rugged mountains and canyons where the species lives, in turn, allowing us to define effects of seasonal weather (and longer-term climate) on the components of population growth. Secondly, we carried out experiments in which we transplanted Clarkia xantiana seeds among different parts of the species' range. These experiments allowed us to tease apart genetic versus environmental sources of variation in how seed survival and germination contribute to population growth, which earlier research had found to be critical. Finally, we used computer models to predict the distribution of land that satisfies the stable- or growing-population criterion of a species' range. We supplemented these central research activities with studies of distributions at smaller spatial scales (i.e., single hillsides) and of the physiological capacities of individual plants, phenomena that define species' niches and "scale up" to their larger geographic distributions.

Serendipitously, the time period of this study spanned a multi-year drought in California, the most severe in recorded history. This event led to some of our most significant findings. We had already identified, at the start of the project, threshold amounts of average rainfall that limit Clarkia xantiana's population growth (and therefore its range) at the range's edges. In the present study's extreme drought, we discovered areas within the species range in which no plants survived to reproduce. We are currently studying whether some of these populations can return, "resurrected" from dormant seeds not killed by the drought, when closer-to-normal rainfall returns. To the extent populations cannot recover, we have documented how a single, extreme event can dramatically alter species distributions. Meanwhile, we discovered that our computer models of species' suitable habitat perform better when we account for the extreme drought, as opposed to accounting only for long-term average rainfall. This means that the current species distribution likely reflects past severe droughts.

The impacts of this research extend well beyond this species. In space and over time, precipitation varies dramatically in California and the American Southwest, where available water dominates not only the distribution and performance of wild species but also agriculture and other human needs. It is likely that the distributions of many wild species bear the imprint of periodic extreme droughts, as well as long term average rainfall. Our research may help predict how land cover of the Southwest will change in a changing climate. The research also has provided educational opportunities for undergraduates at Grinnell College, both via laboratory and greenhouse studies in classes and by mentored research experiences that have helped students develop careers in science, education, and health professions.
